posted_tweets.content: 6 months to ML eng. Or you just start building. Pick one.
Decentralized AI > centralized BS
Decentralized ID > AI demos
Edge inference is crap. Ship or wait.
GPT-5 generates polished UIs with clean code. Putain, what if we use it for SSI interfaces? Simplify identity management with auto-generated, secure UIs. Who's tried this?
AI SDK 6 is out. But let's be real, a unified API for AI providers is just the start. What I want to see is this tech integrated with SSI, making identity management seamless and secure.
Universal Commerce Protocol means one thing for devs: Agent Engine Optimization > SEO. Time to expose your data structure, not just your UI. Who's ready to build for machines, not just humans?

Genspark's $36M ARR in 45 days with no-code agents is wild. But what's crazier? They didn't need to reinvent the wheel. What if we applied this 'build on top' mentality to SSI? Less focus on bespoke auth, more on integrating with what already works.
Claude Opus 4.5 on Vercel's AI Gateway is a beast for coding tasks. But what if we used it to auto-generate SSI interfaces? Simplify identity management with zero UI overhead. Who's tried this?

1. Nhi Nguyen's AI-rebuilt portfolio is a game-changer. But what caught my eye? The 100% AI-architected workflow. Is this the future of dev? | I'm building SSI solutions at Verana and 2060.io, and I see huge potential in AI-driven workflows. Less overhead, more focus on the actual problem. Who's with me? | Time to experiment: can we use AI to simplify SSI integration? Auto-generated code, less errors, more scalability. Let's make it happen.

Vercel's AI Gateway just made OpenAI's GPT-OSS-Safeguard-20B accessible with a unified API. But here's the thing: this consistency is what SSI needs. Imagine seamless content moderation for decentralized identities.
Next.js AI Chatbot 2.0 is out. What caught my eye? Simplified auth setup. No more GitHub OAuth app needed. This is how you onboard devs: less friction, more building.

You think you're a proficient coder? GPT-5.1 Codex Max just dropped on Vercel's AI Gateway. This isn't just an upgrade - it's a coding revolution. You're either ahead of the curve or getting left behind.

You think you're a proficient coder? GPT-5.2 models just dropped on Vercel's AI Gateway. This isn't just an upgrade - it's a coding revolution. You're either ahead of the curve or getting left behind. What will you do with this power?

You're about to witness a coding revolution. Vercel's AI Gateway just made OpenAI's GPT-5.1 Codex models accessible. This isn't just an upgrade - it's a new era of coding. You're either ahead of the curve or getting left behind. What will you do with this power?

You're about to witness a massive shift in coding productivity. Claude Haiku 4.5 is now available on Vercel's AI Gateway, offering Sonnet 4's performance at a lower cost and faster speeds. This kills the old way of coding - you're either adapting or getting left behind.

You're about to witness a seismic shift in coding productivity. Claude Sonnet 4.5 on Vercel AI Gateway doesn't just improve code quality - it redefines how you build and ship. This kills the old way of coding. You're either adapting or getting left behind.

First, you need to identify the specific problem you're trying to solve. Then, you need to choose the right model for the job. Finally, you need to deploy it in a way that scales. The best part? I've got a step-by-step guide to make it | You start by selecting a pre-trained model that aligns with your goals. Then, you fine-tune it using your own dataset. You can generate new training data using techniques like paraphrasing, entity swapping, and more. This kills the old way of relying on massive datasets. You're either adapting to this new reality or getting left behind. | So, what's your next move? You need to understand their pain points and validate your idea. But here's the catch: most developers don't know how to conduct proper customer interviews. You're either asking the right questions

Most developers think building a robust language model like Claude is a monumental task. But what if you could break it down into manageable parts? | First, you need to understand the concept of transfer learning. This isn't just a buzzword - it's a game-changer. By leveraging pre-trained models, you can save thousands of hours of training time. | Next, you need to grasp the importance of data curation. This is where most projects go wrong. You see, the quality of your data is directly proportional to the accuracy of your model. | Now, let's talk about the role of attention mechanisms in language models. This is where things get really interesting. By incorporating attention, you can significantly improve the performance of your model. | But here's the best part: you don't need to build everything from scratch. There are numerous open-source libraries and frameworks that can help you get started. The key is to know which ones to use and how to combine them.

Are you still building on Ethereum without understanding the implications of gas prices on your dApp's scalability? Most developers prioritize short-term gains, but you need to think about the long-term costs - every unnecessary transaction is a tax on your users.
Most CI/CD pipelines are broken because they focus on automation, not reliability. You're either building for 5 nines uptime or you're not building at all.
Are you building decentralized apps without considering the identity layer?
I failed my first side project at 16, but at 19, I'm building the Trust Network & Visualizer at Verana. What changed? You stopped waiting for the perfect idea and started shipping.

Are you still using Node.js without optimizing for performance? Most people focus on coding skills, but the winners master the art of scaling. You need to learn how to leverage Node.js clusters and worker threads to take your apps to the next level.

Most devs build apps without considering scalability. You're either designing for 100 users or 100,000. The difference? A robust architecture. I spent 50 hours optimizing my agency's workflow. Here's what I learned: | You need to prioritize asynchronous processing. Don't let synchronous tasks block your app's growth. Break down large tasks into smaller, manageable chunks. The best part? This approach applies to any programming language. | But here's the catch: most devs focus on coding skills, not scaling. You're either building for 5 nines uptime or you're not building at all. I've seen projects fail due to poor architecture. Don't let that be you. | The key to scalable architecture is simplicity. Don't over-engineer your app. Focus on clean code and modular design. You'll thank me later when you're not debugging a mess of spaghetti code. | Now, let's talk about load balancing. You can't just throw more servers at the problem. You need a strategy. I've found that a combination of horizontal and vertical scaling works best. But what does that mean for your app?

Most people think computer vision is just about object detection. But what if you could use it to optimize your entire development workflow? You're either using CV to automate testing and deployment or you're stuck in manual hell.

I learned today that most indie hackers are building products the wrong way. You're either shipping fast and breaking things or you're overthinking and never launching. The winners don't just build, they create a flywheel of feedback and iteration. | You need to stop romanticizing complexity and focus on simplicity. The best products are not the ones with the most features, but the ones that solve a real problem. I've seen too many indie hackers build something that's perfect, but useless. | But here's the catch: simplicity is not easy. It takes discipline and restraint to build something that's both simple and powerful. You need to be willing to cut features, simplify your code, and focus on the core problem you're trying to solve. | The best way to build a successful product is to create a feedback loop. You launch, you get feedback, you iterate, and you repeat. This is not just about building a product, it's about building a relationship with your users. | I've been building products for years, and I've learned that the most important thing is not the technology, but the people. You need to understand your users, their problems, and their needs. This is not just about building a product, it's about building a community.
Most devs build monoliths. You build microservices.
Building a website with Flash vs building with Next.js: one is a relic, the other is the future.
Most frontend devs are still building monolithic apps. You're either shipping fast with microservices or you're over-engineering a relic.
You're still shipping like it's 2010. Most people do waterfall, but the winners do continuous deployment.

Most people think building a startup means raising funds and hiring a team. The winners, however, start by building something that solves a real problem. You don't need a fancy pitch deck or a big team to create something valuable. You just need to start shipping.
Are you still writing JavaScript like it's 2010?

I still remember the night I spent 12 hours debugging a smart contract, only to realize the issue was a simple gas price miscalculation. You're either building for Web3 with a deep understanding of its complexities or you're just building a fancy database.

You're still building apps without considering the cost of debugging. Most developers prioritize features over reliability. The winners, however, design for debuggability from day one. You're either building for 5 nines uptime or you're not building at all.
Broken pipelines.
Most founders raise funds before validating their product. You build, measure, and iterate first, then scale.
Most people overengineer. You ship or you don't.

You're still issuing credentials like it's 2010. Most people use paper-based IDs, but the winners are building with verifiable credentials. You're either designing for a decentralized future or you're stuck in the past.

Most people think NLP is just about chatbots and language translation. But what if you could use it to revolutionize your entire coding workflow? You're either writing boilerplate code or you're using NLP to generate it. The difference? 10x productivity. | I've been experimenting with NLP-powered code generation for months. Here's what I've learned: you can use it to automate repetitive tasks, generate tests, and even create entire applications from scratch. But here's the catch: it requires a deep understanding of language models. | So, how do you get started with NLP-powered code generation? First, you need to choose a language model that fits your needs. You're either using a pre-trained model or you're training your own. The best part? You can use libraries like Hugging Face to simplify the process. | Once you've chosen your language model, you need to integrate it with your coding workflow. You're either using an API or you're building a custom integration. The key is to automate as much as possible, so you can focus on high-level tasks. | But what about the limitations of NLP-powered code generation? You're either aware of the potential pitfalls or you're going to get burned. The truth is, NLP models are not perfect, and you need to carefully evaluate the generated code to ensure it meets your standards.

96% of new programming languages fail. You're about to learn Rust, a language that's defying those odds. What if the key to its success isn't its performance, but its ability to make you a better programmer?
Ethereum's gas prices are a ticking time bomb. You're either building with scalability in mind or you're designing a relic that will be priced out of existence.

Most devs think building a secure auth system means adding more complexity. The winners, however, know that simplicity is key. You're either building with verifiable credentials or you're just pretending to be secure. | Let's break it down. When you use traditional auth methods, you're essentially trusting a third-party server to manage user identities. But what if you could cut out the middleman and give users full control over their own identities? | Here's the catch: building a decentralized auth system requires a fundamentally different mindset. You need to think about identity as a personal asset, not a commodity to be managed by corporations. The best part? This approach isn't just more secure - it's also more scalable. | So, how do you get started? First, you need to understand the basics of Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI). This means learning about decentralized identifiers, verifiable credentials, and the role of blockchain in identity management. | The key principle of SSI is that users should have full control over their own identities. This means being able to create, manage, and share identity credentials without relying on a centralized authority.

I've spent 200 hours building Node.js apps. Here's what I learned: most people overcomplicate their tech stack. You're either simplifying with microservices or over-engineering a monolith. The winners are shipping fast, not getting stuck in complexity. | You're still using a monolithic architecture because it's "easier". But easier doesn't scale. Breaking down your app into microservices is hard, but it's the only way to achieve true scalability. What's holding you back from making the switch? | The best part? Microservices aren't just for big companies. You can start small and scale up. I've seen it work for startups and side projects alike. But here's the catch: you need to be willing to let go of control and trust your services to do their job. | So, how do you get started with microservices? First, identify the bottlenecks in your current app. What's slowing you down? Then, break out those components into separate services. Finally, use a message queue to tie everything together. | But what about the complexity? Won't microservices just add more moving parts? Yes, they will. But the key is to keep each service simple and focused. You're either building a swarm of small, agile services or a bloated monolith.
Design systems vs one-off UI components: You're either building for scalability or wasting time on relics.

React vs Next.js: Most people choose React for frontend, but the winners use Next.js for server-side rendering. You're either shipping fast and secure, or you're stuck in a world of slow reloads and vulnerabilities.

Most people think a successful launch means raising funds and gaining traction. The winners, however, know that a launch is just a starting point - it's the iterations and improvements that follow that truly matter. You're either building to learn or you're launching to fail.

Most Python developers are still writing code like they're paid by the line. You're either building concise, readable functions or you're wasting everyone's time, including your own. What's the one thing you can do today to simplify your codebase?

I've analyzed 500 startup pitches. 80% fail because they prioritize features over scalability. You're either building to last or designing a relic that will be replaced in a year. The winners know that scalability is key from day one. | So, how do you build a scalable startup? First, you need to identify your bottlenecks. Where will your app break when it scales? You can't just throw more resources at the problem; you need to design for scalability from the ground up. | But here's the catch: most startups don't have the resources to build a scalable infrastructure from scratch. That's why you need to prioritize. What are the core features that will drive your growth? Focus on those and cut everything else. The best part? | You don't need to build everything yourself. There are tools and platforms that can help you scale faster and more efficiently. For example, using a serverless architecture can save you time and money in the long run. But you need to know when to use them. | So, what's the secret to building a scalable startup? It's not about being the first to market or having the most features. It's about being the most efficient and adaptable. You need to be able to pivot quickly and respond to changes in the market.

Static typing vs Dynamic typing: Most developers choose dynamic typing for flexibility, but the winners use static typing for scalability. You're either catching errors at compile time or wasting hours debugging.

I still remember my first failed deployment like it was yesterday. I spent 48 hours setting up a CI/CD pipeline, only to have it break on the first push. The emotion was frustration, but the lesson was invaluable: you don't truly understand CI/CD until you've broken it. | Most people think CI/CD is just about automation, but the winners know it's about creating a feedback loop that informs every stage of development. | So, how do you build a CI/CD pipeline that actually works? First, you need to identify your bottlenecks. Where are the pain points in your current pipeline? Are you spending too much time on manual testing? Are your deployments taking too long? | Once you've identified your bottlenecks, it's time to optimize. You can use tools like Jenkins or GitLab CI/CD to automate your testing and deployment. But here's the catch: automation is only half the battle. | I've seen too many teams get stuck in the "build, break, fix" cycle. They build a pipeline, it breaks, and then they spend hours fixing it. But what if you could break that cycle? What if you could build a pipeline that's resilient, scalable, and maintainable?

I still remember the night I spent 12 hours debugging a simple authentication issue, only to realize I had misplaced a comma. Most people think debugging is about being smart, but the winners know it's about being systematic.

You're still building monolithic apps like it's 2010. The winners are building with microservices and serverless architecture. You're either scaling with the best or designing a relic that will be obsolete in 6 months. | Most people think microservices are too complex, but the truth is, they're simpler than you think. You just need to break down your app into smaller, independent functions. | But here's the catch: most people fail at microservices because they don't plan for scalability. You need to design your app to handle 10x the traffic you expect. The best part? This forces you to write cleaner, more efficient code. | You're either writing code that's concise and readable or you're wasting everyone's time. With microservices, you can focus on one function at a time, making it easier to debug and maintain. I've seen this firsthand with my own projects, like Concieragent. | The biggest advantage of microservices is that they allow you to innovate faster. You can try new things, experiment with new tech, and deploy quickly without affecting the entire app. This is how the winners stay ahead of the curve.
Most code is bloated. You're either stripping it down or drowning in tech debt.
**You're still building APIs like it's 2010.**

Most people think shipping code means clicking a button and hoping for the best. The winners, however, know that shipping is a deliberate process that requires careful planning and execution. You're either shipping with intention or you're wasting your time. | So, what does it mean to ship with intention? It starts with defining a clear goal for your project. What problem are you trying to solve, and how will you measure success? You need to be able to answer these questions before you start writing code. | Once you have a clear goal, it's time to break it down into smaller, manageable tasks. This is where most people go wrong. They try to tackle too much at once and end up getting bogged down in complexity. | But here's the catch: even with a clear goal and a solid plan, things won't always go as expected. That's where iteration comes in. You need to be willing to pivot and adjust your approach as you learn more about your project and your users. | So, how do you know when you're ready to ship? It's simple: you're never really "ready." There will always be something that could be improved or tweaked. But if you've been shipping with intention, you'll know that you've done everything you can to set yourself up for success.

You just learned that most Minimum Viable Products are actually Maximum Viable Products - bloated with features that nobody uses. What if you stripped it down to the bare essentials and shipped in 48 hours, not 4 weeks?
Most machine learning models are black boxes. You're either building explainable AI or you're building a liability. The winners know that transparency is key to scalability.

DeFi vs TradFi: You're either building on decentralized networks or perpetuating a broken system. Most people think DeFi is just a fad, but the winners know it's the future of finance. You're either all-in on decentralization or you're already behind.

Most people think building a decentralized app means starting from scratch. The winners know that's a waste of time. You're either using existing protocols to speed up development or you're falling behind. I spent 50 hours integrating Verifiable Credentials into my project. | Here's what I learned: you don't need to be a cryptography expert to build with decentralized identity. The hardest part is understanding how to design a system that's both secure and user-friendly. You're either designing for simplicity or you're losing users. | The key to building a successful decentralized app is to focus on the user experience. You're either making it easy for users to manage their own identity or you're creating a hurdle that will drive them away. | But here's the catch: building a decentralized app isn't just about tech - it's about understanding the social implications of giving users control over their own identity. | The best part? You don't need to wait for the "perfect" protocol to start building. You can start using existing tools like Verifiable Credentials and Decentralized Identifiers to create a more secure and user-friendly experience. The winners are already shipping.
You're one parametric tweak away from a deep learning breakthrough

Building a Python app vs building a Python framework: Most people choose the former because it's safe. But you're either creating a solution for yourself or paving the way for others. Which one are you doing?

Most web designers still build sites like it's 2010. You're either creating static, unresponsive layouts or you're building dynamic, user-centric experiences. The winners know that web design is no longer just about aesthetics, but about crafting immersive interactions. | You're still using bloated CSS frameworks and outdated HTML templates. The best web designers, however, have moved on to modern tools like Next.js and TypeScript. You're either stripping down your codebase or drowning in technical debt. | But here's the catch: even with the right tools, most web designers still prioritize form over function. You're either building sites that convert or you're just creating digital brochures. The best part? It's not that hard to make the switch. | To create truly immersive web experiences, you need to focus on four key areas: responsive design, interactive elements, accessible interfaces, and seamless navigation. You're either designing with these principles in mind or you're just guessing. | So, what does it take to build a website that truly engages users? It starts with a deep understanding of user behavior and a willingness to experiment with new technologies. You're either pushing the boundaries of web design or you're just playing it safe.

I've bootstrapped 3 projects in the last year, and I've learned that 90% of founders waste their time on the wrong things. You're either building to solve a real problem or you're building to impress your friends. The difference? Focus on the 3 core principles of bootstrapping. | First, you need to validate your idea. Most people skip this step and end up building something nobody wants. You're either talking to potential customers or you're guessing. I've seen too many projects fail because they didn't take the time to understand their target market. | Second, you need to build a minimum viable product (MVP) that solves the problem. Most people overcomplicate this step and end up with a bloated product. You're either stripping it down to the essentials or you're drowning in feature creep. | But here's the catch: most people don't know how to measure the success of their MVP. You're either tracking the right metrics or you're flying blind. I've learned that it's not about the number of users, but about the engagement and retention. | The best part? Bootstrapping forces you to be creative with your resources. You're either finding ways to optimize your budget or you're burning out. I've learned to prioritize my spending and focus on the things that truly matter.
Most people build Web3 apps with a centralized mindset. You're either decentralizing every layer or you're just building a fancy database.

Building AI models vs building AI frameworks: Most people choose the former because it's safe. But you're either creating a solution for yourself or you're building a foundation for others. I've spent 100 hours building AI frameworks. Here's what I've learned. | You're probably using pre-trained models without understanding the underlying architecture. The winners, however, know that true power lies in building custom frameworks that can adapt to any problem. You're either stuck in a black box or you're designing your own. | But here's the catch: building AI frameworks requires a deep understanding of the math behind the models. You're either willing to put in the work or you're doomed to repeat the same mistakes. | The best part? Once you understand the fundamentals, you can build anything. You're no longer limited to pre-trained models or outdated architectures. You're either building the future or you're stuck in the past. | But what if you don't have 100 hours to spare? What if you're stuck with limited resources and a tight deadline? That's where the real challenge lies. You're either able to distill complex concepts into simple, actionable steps or you're lost in the noise.
Are you still trusting servers with your credentials?
Monolithic apps vs Microservices: You're either building lego towers or skyscrapers.

I've spent 200 hours building frontend projects. Here's what I learned: most developers are still building websites like it's 2010. You're either using outdated tech or you're building dynamic, user-centric experiences with modern frameworks like Next.js.
Most apps still ship with insecure defaults.

Builder mindset vs Consumer mindset: You're either creating the future or waiting for someone else to build it for you. Most people think innovation is about waiting for the next big thing, but the winners know that shipping code and solving real problems is what truly drives
96% of deep learning models are over-engineered. You're either simplifying or sinking.

Most neural networks are over-engineered. You're either simplifying your models or sinking in technical debt. I've spent 100 hours optimizing my own neural networks and here's what I learned: the key to efficient models lies in pruning, not adding more layers.
You're building microservices like it's a religion. But most people forget that 80% of their codebase is still a monolith. You're either optimizing for scale or drowning in technical debt.
